title: line-of-duty-star-adrian-dunbar-teases-a-surprise-twist
story: As the fourth series drew to a close in , there was a gasp-inducing moment that saw many viewers emit a visceral howl of anguish. There was Ted looking a bit shty, right when it seemed that everything has been tied up neatly in a bow.Whether Ted could be ldquoH, the corrupt police officer with a hand in almost every diabolical conspiracy running through Jed Mercuriorsquos award-winning police procedural since it began in , has become the subject of feverish speculation among the showrsquos fans.Adding fuel to the flames, a BBC promo shot shows Hastings handcuffed to fellow AC- officers DS Steve Arnott and DI Kate Fleming, played by Martin Compston and Vicky McClure, with a tagline that reads: ldquoCrime needs an inside man.As Dunbarrsquos dulcet Northern Irish tones drt down the line, I opt to tackle the swirling rumours head-on. Please say itrsquos not so, Adrian hellipldquoAt the end of the last series there was this indication that Ted was under some kind of suspicion and that is followed through on, says Dunbar. ldquoIt does not look very good for Ted, I have to say.ldquoEverybody is going to have to hang tough with the whole thing because it unravels bit by bit across the full series. He does come under suspicion and that is followed through on.Gulp hellip The fth series of Line of Duty, which gets under way this evening, will centre on organised crime groups .Itrsquos been two years since we last caught up with AC- ndash Mercurio has been off making hit BBC thriller Bodyguard starring Richard Madden ndash and as the new series begins viewers are immediately thrust into the action when a balaclava-clad gang ambushes a police convoy.Fans will be delighted to learn there are plenty of classic-style Line of Duty moments to look forward to over the coming weeks, including jaw-dropping twists, shock betrayals, grisly crime scenes, marathon interrogations ndash and, yes, those delicious Ted-isms.Dunbarrsquos character has garnered quite the following for his phraseology and quick one-linerswith the actor deftly introducing a clutch of Northern Irish colloquialisms such as ldquofella and ldquonow wersquore suckinrsquo diesel that didnrsquot appear in the original scripts.ldquoI had no idea these things were going to catch on, he laughs. ldquoOr that people would be playing pub games with them. Ted Hastings bingo  ldquoYes, it is a bit mad. I have got a good one coming up ndash I think it is in episode one ndash but Irsquom not going to tell you what it is. It is a real bang-on Belfast one.The eldest of seven children, Dunbar, , grew up in Enniskillen where his late father was a carpenter and his mother worked as a cook. As a teenager he aspired be a musician but then found acting after a cousin introduced him to a local amateur drama group.Dunbar studied at Guildhall School of Music and Drama in London and went on to roles in critically-acclaimed films such as Hear My Song and The Crying Game. Hersquos been a regular on our screens over the past four decades, popping up in A Touch of Frost, Silent Witness and Ashes to Ashes.Since , hersquos played Hastings in Line of Duty and his fondness for the character is palpable. Showrunner Mercurio is said to have initially envisaged the AC- boss as more of a shambolic figurehead in the beguiling manner of TV detective Columbo, as played by Peter Falk.When Dunbar was cast and brought his own take on Hastings, Mercurio saw the strength in having a proactive and dynamic leader who would also be a mentor to Arnott and Fleming.ldquoHe [Mercurio] realised the series needed that person, somebody who is bright, tough, sharp and could handle dficult scenarios, says Dunbar.ldquoTed is old school. I think people like that about him. But he is also quite vulnerable and insecure sometimes, so it is not all kick the door in. He is tough where the letter of the law is concerned but he is not entirely a tough person himself.Dunbar says he drew inspiration from the style of great Scottish footballing managers such as Jock Stein, Bill Shankly and Alex Ferguson when breathing le into Hastings.ldquoHe has a good man management style and sense of morality, he says. ldquoThat kind of character who has a way with people and they trust him. They know that ultimately, evenit is to his own detriment, he will always do the right thing.Line of Duty is set in an unspecied, generic Midlands town. The first series was shot in Birmingham with subsequent episodes filmed in Northern Ireland, chiefly around Belfast.That suits Dunbar down to a tee. ldquoI love going back to Northern Ireland, he enthuses. ldquoMe and Martin [Compston] often talk about the idea that we might get a sht over to Glasgow some year, but that has not happened as yet. We could have a right laughwe got to Glasgow as well.ldquoBelfast is great. It is a small city and we can get around it easily enough. We have got to know it really well over the years. Of course, for me, itrsquos great because I get to see friends and my family can come to see me ndash all that kind of craic.The actor has often spoken about striving to keep his own accent for roles whenever possible because he believes it lends greater authenticity.ldquoIt is always important to get regional accents up there, asserts Dunbar. ldquoWhen you think of the likes of Bill Paterson or the guys who came out of : bringing Scottish accents to the screen and not feeling the necessity to change their accents.ldquoBut also, I think it really fits the part [in Line of Duty]. I wouldnrsquot try and do itit didnrsquot. It fits the part to have [Hastings] speak like that.ldquoThere are aspects about it that are useful such as the fact he was an RUC officer and he would have had training in anti-terrorism which figures a lot in AC-.ldquoWhen he comes to head up AC- he is an outsider. There is nobody in the rest of the police force that you would think would be able to get to him on a personal level or who would know him from before. All those things help to locate him as being from Northern Ireland.Compston revealed during an earlier series that his estuary English twang as Arnott began to slip slightly, seeing his own Greenock accent begin to creep in, due to exhaustion as the gruelling filming schedules took their toll.At least Dunbar doesnrsquot need to worry about that  ldquoNo, thatrsquos right, he chuckles. Although thatrsquos not to say Line of Dutyrsquos famed kne-edge interrogation scenes are a doddle to shoot. In fact, far from it as Dunbar can testy.ldquoThose things are very tough, he says. ldquoI have to learn sometimes  pages at a time. The takes can last  minutes ndash we do big, long takes. You always hope that you get a couple of days in between so you can learn the next one because you canrsquot keep everything in your head at the one time.ldquoPolice are allowed to look at their notes so, some of the actors, they can look down at their notes and see what is coming up next. But I canrsquot do that because I donrsquot wear glasses in the part, soI look down, I canrsquot see anything. I have to learn everything. Which is fine but it is tough.Line of Duty has earned a reputation for its high calibre of guest stars who have included Keeley Hawes, Daniel Mays and Thandie Newton among others.The latest series is no exception with Boardwalk Empire and This Is England actor Stephen Graham joining the cast as the elusive ldquoBalaclava Man and Rochenda Sandall, known for her roles in Black Mirror and Love, Lies and Records, as AC-rsquos formidable suspect, Lisa McQueen.Does bringing in names like this help keep things fresh  ldquoI think so but the main thing is that Jed keeps the standard of his work up, says Dunbar. ldquoUnbelievably, he seems to be able to do that every time. When we come in and read the new scripts, we are always very excited.ldquoBut then, of course, you have to marry those new characters with great actors. Martin and Vicky are two grounded and truthful actors. That standard has been kept up all the way through.ldquoThe believability of the series is very important to us. The likes of Stephen and Rochenda are bang on the money as regards the type of actor and acting we love.You might imagine Dunbar would be inundated with fans hoping to glean spoilers but thatrsquos not the case. ldquoNever, he insists. ldquoPeople come up and say: lsquoWe absolutely love Line of Duty ndash donrsquot tell me anything.rsquo They like to watch it in real time and want to be thrilled by the next twist or turn.As for what he enjoys most  ldquoThe acting I get to do with the role. The decisions I have to make and all the things emotionally that he has to go through. Actors are like race horses. They like to run ndash they donrsquot like to be hanging about. The part gives me lots of hard work to do and thatrsquos enjoyable.Line of Duty begins on BBC One, tonight, pm

title: paul-hutcheon-revoking-article-50-would-be-fair-to-remain-and-leave-voters
story: Noble words, no doubt, and a welcome departure from previous Tory administrations where cynical realpolitik was the guiding principle of foreign policy. Alas, support for Saudi Arabia and other autocracies perhaps undermines the lofty rhetoric.However, take the policy intention at face value and imagine the FCO staging a seminar tomorrow on exporting the Westminster brand of democracy across the globe.In explaining the last three years, civil servants would have to run through how Theresa May, in compounding the follies of her hapless predecessor, had committed the most appalling series of blunders of any Prime Minister in a century.She triggered the Brexit process without having any idea of what she wanted to achieve. She set ldquored lines that were entirely aimed at her own MPs, many of whom are so zealous that they would never support her. Her eventual deal was easily rejected three times by Parliament. And the same legislature voted down all other alternatives.The FCO seminar would have to conclude that the UK had gone from being viewed as a beacon of democracyto a laughing stock. Westminster proceedings are getting more coverage around the world than ever before, but not for positive reasons. MPs should dread the next poll on faith in our democratic institutions.But the humiliation of the House of Commons as an institution should not result in us shying away from asking the most fundamental question - what is the solution to this crisis In a repeat of last weekrsquos debacle, MPs will tomorrow vote on a raft of alternatives to the May deal which,passed, could form the basis of a radically dferent offer to European negotiators. Other options, which wonrsquot be voted on, are also in the mix.In what will inevitably dominate the news cycles next week, May is expected to bring back her discredited Withdrawal Agreement again. It is an understandable tactic in theory, but in practice the pro-Remain Speaker of the House will be unlikely to accede to Government demands. John Bercow blocked a third ldquomeaningful" vote on the grounds that little had changed from the second snub it seems improbable he would jettison his own ruling.A ldquoconfirmatory vote, which was narrowly rejected last week, will probably come back but the plan is problematic on a number of fronts. Hatched by two Labour MPs from very dferent constituencies, the idea is simple: Mayrsquos deal is pitted against Remain in a public vote, the result of which would be legally binding.However, such a move would be unfair to Leave voters. Mayrsquos deal has been ridiculed and is tarnished. Half the pro-Brexit side would probably sit out a referendumher deal was on the ballot. For any second referendum to pass the fairness test , voters would need to be presented with a Brexit option backed by Leavers. The current "deal", by contrast, is lying in the gutter, promoted by a Prime Minister who looks like a zombie in The Walking Dead.Labour and the SNP have suggested that a general election would be an appropriate response to this catastrophe. I can see why political parties, eyeing electoral gain, would find this option attractive, but its dficult to argue that going back to the voters will somehow break the deadlock and produce a workable solution. Parliament is ided because the country is ided.Consider a new Tory leader, elected on a  of ripping up the May plan and starting negotiations again with the EU, winning a majority at the polls. It is conceivable, at a push, to imagine a comfortable majority of Tory MPs endorsing a harder form of Brexit, but it almost impossible to envisage the EU signing up to this fantasy. Mayrsquos deal is the hardest form of Brexit the EU will agree to.A Corbyn premiership would run in to even bigger problems. Given the Labour leaderrsquos euro-scepticism, he would contest the next election on a commitment to deliver a ldquoLabour Brexit, which would be softer than the May plan. But just as the right-wing European Research Group has tortured May, so too would Corbynrsquos colleagues try to sabotage his blueprint. Most Labour MPs, like the party membership, are staunchly pro-Remain and would revoltit appeared that the leadership was attempting to implement Brexit.The so-called ldquosoft Brexit options have the best chance of securing MP backing this week. Tory veteran Ken Clarkersquos customs union plan fell by a handful of votes. His colleague Nick Bolesrsquo suggestion of a ldquoCommon Market . also looks like a strong runner, particularlythe SNP back it on tactical grounds. It is not beyond the wit of man to imagine a form of words being devised that commands a parliamentary majority.However, a ldquosoft Brexit ndash loosely based on Norwayrsquos close relationship with the EU ndash looks like the worst of all worlds. Norway is not a member of the EU, but must abide by freedom of movement and is also bound by single market rules that it has little say over. For want of a better cliche, the UK would become a rule-taker, not a rule-maker. It would be the opposite of taking back control and further damage the reputation of Westminster.The solution lies in understanding the root of the current problem. In a fatal mistake in , Mayinvoked the Article  process on the UKrsquos withdrawal, thus setting a deadline on the EU and MPs reaching an agreement. She did so without having an indication of the type of deal that could get passed by both sides. We are now in a position of begging the EU for mercy.Two options present themselves. The first, in recognition that Parliament cannot agree on a way forward, is to seek a y extension from the EU, probably in the region of  months. Earlier this year, the Herald on Sunday published impassioned pleas from range of figures across civic Scotland who backed an extension earlier this year, and they were right to do so. However, it contains the drawback of setting another articial deadline.A better solution would be to revoke Article , an option that is on the table thanks to a court case pursued by Scottish parliamentarians. This would not be about stopping Brexit, but would instead give MPs and the public a chance to breathe without the stress of   melodrama and stories about medicine shortages. More than  million people voted Leave in  they did not vote to Leave on March , or April . A date was not on the ballot.Halting the process would allow May to stand down and for the the Tories to elect a successor in a contest that would not have to be rushed. It could result in a general election and a change of Government. It would allow a national conversation to take place on the type of Brexit the country wants, and whether it should be put to a referendum. It would take no deal off the table. It is time to stop the clock.Even then, revocation would require our politicians to stop acting in their own narrow party interests, and start recognising that the future of country is at stake. The present conditions are ripe for extremism ... and Westminster should be aware of that, and act accordingly.

title: joanna-blythman-reviews-nero-a-meta-in-edinburgh
story: We soon realise that the food here isnrsquot what wersquod expected. Therersquos complimentary homemade ricotta bread, which is interesting- reasonable yeasted bread with a ripple of the curdy cheese and black pepper through it. My dining partner thinks it lacks salt but at this point Irsquom not rushing to judgement. Several regions of Italy make bread without any salt itrsquos traditional. But I do agree that a little sodium chloride would improve it.Starters proper are a mixed bag. Involtini- melting cabbage leaf rolls filled with potatoes, Italian pork sausage, and Pecorino fondue- is the best of the bunch: homely, comforting, spiked by the potency of the long-aged cheese.The menu says that the Puglian burrata cheese comes with a baked potato timbale and sea salt-infusedolives. The potato doo-dah reminds me of my failed attempts at potato latkes I gave up on them. The burrata is fine, not exceptional. The cold cheese warm potato thing isnrsquot an instant winner, and without the salty, dry black olives, this dish would be terribly bland. We try the slow-cooked tripe with Borlotti beans, guancialeand bay leaves. The offal is easy to eatutterly tasteless, and the beans are, well, beans. title: the-year-the-edinburgh-international-festival-embraced-politics-inside-the-eifs-radical-vision-for-2019
story: And the culmination of the  Edinburgh International Festivals concentrated look at our turbulent political and social times will be a new Manesto for the Future written by  leading writers over the Scottish capitals festival season.There have been, over the last five years, the series of free opening concerts, which this year will see Heart of Midlothians Tynecastle Park turned into an arena for the Los Angeles Philharmonic, led by its superstar conductor Gustavo Dudamel.But this years festival, which takes place from August -, is dferent in a new way.The  You Are Here shows, collectively, looks at issues of domestic violence, urban violence, gender, race, sexuality, class, and colonial legacies.The strand of work features performances which could possibly be imagined as being on the Fringe: smaller works in a new intimate venue, the Studio at the Royal Lyceum, that holds around  people.In an exclusive interview with the Herald on Sunday, Linehan said: "Yoursquove always got to push in dferent directions. You can feel what is out there, in the ether."To not be coming to some kind of positive conversation about things at the moment, feels like fiddling while Rome burns."We spoke in his sparse office at the top of The Hub, the EIFs base at the top of the Royal Mile, two days before the  programme was officially revealed to the world. Linehan added: "Itrsquos also driven by the fact that there are so many artists right now, who are really wanting to address bigger questions. Generationally, therersquos also a sense of that."Itrsquos not agitprop [art as propaganda], because a lot of it is storytelling ndash its not just taking a political position and hammering it home. But it is talking about some of things ndash whether its talking about the environment, or gender issues, or whatever  ndash and addressing them quite directly. Its something that is there in the programme as a season, but it is also informing what we do more generally."It also gives us the chance to be more flexible, to have more work from Burkina Faso or the Lebanon or Greenland: to be able to spread our wings in terms of the programme."McGrath said the festival, which was formed in the aftermath of the devastations of the Second World War in , is also thinking about its place in a world in turmoil, and looking ahead to its th birthday in .She said: "I think there is something very interesting and resonant in approaching the birthday, and thinking about the beginnings of the festival, and thinking that arts and culture might have a role to play in redefining or re-articulating what citizenship might be, or what internationalism might be."McGrath added: "In the st century, in the times we are living in, what really does citizenship mean  What are our responsibility to ourselves and others in a very changed world. What does internationalism now mean  Here we are, at the end of March, wondering what that means for the UK. This feels like an incredible opportunity to think about it in a properly international context."These are international artists, thinking about migration, climate change, changing ideas about identity, equality...it feels like theres some really big stuff that artists are grappling with."At the heart of You Are Here is the three week-long conference of  writers from around the worldwho will, at the end of the festival, reveal a new "manesto for the world". Their conference will have three parts daily: the Morning Manesto, where ideas and beliefs will be discussed, Call and Response at pm, and in the evening, Breaking Bread, where audiences will be able to have a meal with an artist.This group, led by David Greig, the playwright and artistic director of the Royal Lyceum, is being inspired by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which was made in .McGrath, who is also director of Fuel theatre company, said: "We were thinking of bringing something new to the festival. It felt appealing to me in that a lot of the work I have been doing is looking at extraordinary artists, that have an unusual perspective or insight into the world, and the ability to share that with an audience in a way that holds within it the possibility of change ... and of engaging in the world we live in."These are artists who are really trying to engage in the big questions of our times."The shows in the new strand include Hear Word! Naija Woman Talk True, which will feature  of Nigerias biggest stars of stage and screen on stage to tell "multi-generational stories of inequality and transformation".La Reprise by Milo Rau, an oft controversial star of theatre, is an "audacious piece of investigative theatre" which looks at the violent, real-le murder in Belgium of Ihsane Jarfi in  .Red Dust Road is also part of the strand, the National Theatre of Scotlands production of the Makar Jackie Kays memoir, which has been adapted for the stage by Tanika Gupta.Other shows include Purposeless Movements, by Birds of Paradise theatre company, written by Robert Softley Gale, a leading disabled Scottish artist and writer of My Left Right Foot ndash The Musical.Hard to be Soft: a Belfast Prayer, by Oona Doherty, the Belfast-based choreographer and dancer, will look "behind the masks of violence and machismo to the inner lives of Belfast hard men and strong women."Softley Gale said: "Of course EIF must be addressing current, political issues - this is core to art in  staying relevant to our society."Disabled people make up % of the population and have a right to see themselves, their lives and their experiences reflected in the world around them."But perhaps more importantly, the wider population need and want to see stories that havent been explored yet - the stories of disabled people need to become an integral part of our Scottish culture."Linehan said that while each show tackles all kinds of issues, the strand does not posit one particular view of the world. He said that he acknowledges that the audiences at the Festival ndash particularly given their international make-up ndash may not have a consensus on how they view the world at its issues.He said: "We donrsquot have a particular didactic point."Its more that there is such complexity in the world ndash and given that with all the festivals we have the great social gathering of the world, and also a great cultural gathering ndash I think that is fair to say: How is that responding to a world that is in a real state of flux "I mean, we talked a lot about  being about citizenship, and what it means to be a citizen of a place  I think Edinburgh is having a conversation about that as well. So why do you draw that circle, of where you are from and what you have responsibility for: but that can be done with a great sense of fun."And that is something that Edinburgh has always had, the capacity to mix its seriousness with a quite Bacchanalian madness as well."McGrath says that the new strand is a "pilot" for future work of the same kind, a word that Linehan also uses.That You Are Here is happening at all is due to some combined forces: the British Council, the University of Edinburgh Futures Institute, as well as Place funding, the new poundm funding potprovided by the Scottish Government, City of Edinburgh Council and Edinburgh Festivals.She added: "Edinburgh has this extraordinary history of being at the forefront of conversations about what citizenship is, what a civic society might mean or be, and it is changing now."I grew up in Edinburgh, and moved away, and now having an opportunity to relearn and rediscover Edinburgh: it is a fascinating, rich and lots of opportunities for the festival to develop its relationship with the people of the city."For the festival, the new strand of work allows it to stage smaller works, which are maybe too intricate or pricey for a risky run at the Fringe, but are not the expansive EIF shows which audiences have come to expect in the last  years in size, scale and budget.Linehan said: ldquoOne of the things we realised, we did feel there is a certain type of midscale work, that is more geographically erse than what we have been doing.ldquoThey cannot play on the Fringe, because they are too complex and too expensive. Itrsquos not an opera company, or a huge European theatre company, but we are kind of missing it. So we wanted to put that in. And so that has created this ndash these are not necessarily huge pieces - but there is a block in the middle there of midscale work that is all quite socially engaged. It also gives it much more of a geographical reach, much more geographical erse, and it is a little less Eurocentric."Linehan says that the new programming allows for artists such as Rou or the choreographer Serge Aime Coulibaly t come to the EIF: Coulibaly is presenting Kalakuta Republik, a work inspired by the music and le of Fela Kuti.He says: "Milo Rou, the most talked about European director at the moment, Serge Coulibaly, again, one of the most talked about directors: these guys yoursquod never see them at the Fringe."They wouldnrsquot set up a tent for % of the box office at the Fringe and give it a go. There was always a thing in Edinburgh actually. Do you define the Fringe versus International festival by dint of scale  That always created something of a gap, with a whole range of artists, who didnrsquot necessarily want to do big, big work, but whose work was complex and they were still senior artists. It meant that a lot of artists were just not coming through here."Linehan said that The Departure Lounge series, led by Greig, may also point to new material for the festival in the future. In a sense, the festival itself may be generating new shows through this years activities.He said: "All of these things are piloting how we might be able to use the festival beyond the lsquoCome in and do your four performances, and well get you back out to the airport.rsquoSo, I ask, it is a way of generating its own material in some way He says: "Well, generating its own material but also using a combination of the artists, people here in Edinburgh, and people of a shared interest, to be able to talk about things. But within the framework of some kind of performance or social event. Rather than a much more passive event, like a talk."This years new programming will be an experiment, and, it seems, a template for further evolution of the EIF.McGrath added: "How incredible is Edinburgh that  writers from  countries can, over the course of a month, have a conversation with people from the city, locals and visitors, about what a manesto for the future will look like "By the end of the month, they will have collectively created some kind of aspirational manesto for the future: we shall see what happens. But it seems like a brilliant starting point for a lot of interesting conversations."

title: Iain Macwhirter  As May goes down for the third time  the road to Brexit just got a whole lot longer
story: The Prime Minister has behaved asshe had a thumping Commons majority when in fact she is a minority leader of an unstable coalition. Even after the Damascene conversion of arch-Brexiter Jacob Rees-Mogg, who used to described her deal as ldquovassalage, her final attempt to get a stripped-down Withdrawal Agreement through Parliament failed on Friday by a substantial majority. You have to give May full marks for her consistency: everything she touches turns to dust, even her own resignation.But thatrsquos by the by. As everyone has been saying: we are where we are. And where we are is extremely uncomfortable. Brexiters are gearing up to have a belly laugh at the opposition MPs, who will do their best throughout the coming week to find a compromise. Who do they think they are  Playing at being a provisional government  ldquoItrsquos like allowing the whelk stall to be run by the whelks, according to the Tory MP Sir Bill Cash. Butno-one  is able to run the eponymous stall, then all power to the whelks.Last weekrsquos indicative votes suggested that MPs are broadly in favour of a Brexit that keeps Britain in the EUrsquos economic loop while leaving the political institutions. Curiously, the SNP, who have been arguing for soft Brexit in two white papers and an election manesto, decided not to vote for the ious options, even the Norway model that they have long extolled. The SNP did, however, vote for the proposal from the Labour MP Margaret Beckett for a confirmatory ballot, and this option got the largest number of votes, much to everyonersquos surprise. This must be a serious possibility now that Parliament has failed to resolve the Brexit conundrum.However, this is not a Peoplersquos Vote as some have styled it. A confirmatory vote is not a rerun of the  referendum, but strictly a chance for voters to give their views on whatever deal Parliament agrees . The Kyle Wilson Amendment originally envisaged putting the Prime Ministerrsquos deal to a popular vote, assuming it was passed by Parliament. However, this confirmatory referendum might be dficult to schedule because it could collide with three other elections: a Tory leadership election, the European elections and a General Election. Brenda from Bristol will be in despair.EvenMPs fail to come up with a working compromise, they can still block a no-deal Brexit. The majority against leaving the EU without a deal is overwhelming. This means May, or her successor, will have to go cap-in-hand to Brussels in the next few days and request another, longer delay to Article . This would mean Britain participating in the European elections in May, which excites the Independent Group of Tory and Labour rebels, but is looked upon with dread by the main parties. Brussels too is worried about populist contagion spreading to other EU countries like Italy, but they are legally bound to make British participation a condition of any further extension to AVoter wrath, particularly in Labourrsquos leave constituencies, could lead to a dramatic revival of Nigel Faragersquos Ukip, or worse. The Svengali behind the  Vote Leave campaign, Dominic Cummings, is gearing up for the fight and reportedly suggesting a new party to fight for the right to leave. ldquoTell them again is the favoured slogan. The European elections might themselves turn into a kind of second referendum on Brexit.The Tories will presumably have a new leader by then, since Theresa May will surely go now there is to be the long extension she has resolutely opposed. Mind you, it is impossible to guess the Prime Ministerrsquos thought processes. She said she would goher withdrawal deal passed on Friday. But her gambit didnrsquot work. Even the opportunity to dispense with Mayrsquos services was not sufficient inducement for the Democratic Unionist Party to come on board. The joke doing the rounds last week was that she tried to fall on her sword and missed.But these things have a momentum of their own, and the Tory leadership election has already begun. Boris Johnson is the narrow frontrunner, but that could change. He might win the membership, but under Tory rules the parliamentary party has to agree the two candidates put to a postal ballot. The remainers in the Tory benches might use this as an opportunity to foil the hard Brexiters by keeping Boris off the list.Of course, what should happen when a government fails to get its most important legislation through Parliament is not a leadership election, but a General Election. The government cannot govern and, even with the Fixed-term Parliaments Act, this should lead to a General Election via a vote of no confidence. Some Conservatives might prefer to fight a General Election than European elections they had promised would never take place. But events are now out of everyonersquos control.Everyone, that is, except the EU, which now holds Britainrsquos future in the balance. Itrsquos trying not to crow about Britainrsquos abject national humiliation, but the , not the UK Parliament, will now decide the UKrsquos immediate future: deal or no deal. If MPs agree this week to back a soft Brexit involving the customs union and alignment with the single market, Brussels has promised to fast-track it in a matter of days. But the alternative, a long extension, will also suit the European Union.That means more money from Britainrsquos budget contribution, and serves as a warning to other EU countries about the dangers of trying to leave the Union. It also holds out the possibility of Britain remaining in the EU,a referendum is eventually staged.Well, that remains to be seen. What is perhaps more likely is that Britain gets stuck indefinitely in a long extension. It emerged last week that the Democratic Unionist Party, which again voted against Mayrsquos withdrawal deal, could live with a long extension. Indeed, they signalled that they could live with a customs union ndash as long as it ensured no border between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK. The DUP may be Brexiters, but they are ardent Unionists first.A soft Brexit may now be the best way of keeping the UK together. But it should be put to the people in a confirmatory vote,for no other reason than this was not what most people thought they were voting for in . MPs have the opportunity to decide this tomorrow.How and why Theresa May failed to seek the only kind of Brexit that could get through Parliament will be left for historians to judge. One of her own Cabinet ministers, quoted on BBC Newsnight, gave the provisional verdict: ldquoShersquos the sole architect of this mess because of her inability to engage in the most basic human interaction. Who says personalities donrsquot matter in great historical events

title: herald-on-sunday-letters-what-readers-think-about-brexit-independence-language-and-the-future-of-the-highlands
story: The UK as a whole had circa , students studying abroad while receiving , in our institutions. The scheme extends to academic staff as well, and , teachers went from the UK to other EU countries for training while we received ,. Erasmus also extends to vocational training, which was balanced , outgoing to , incoming.Our utilisation of Erasmus is not in proportion to our budget contribution. We should position ourselves like Switzerland and invest the retained Brexit idend in our own colleges and universities, while continuing to attract the most innovative researchers from around the world.Tom WalkerLoanheadYour correspondent D.B.McNally is angry, and rightly so . He asks "will our Scottish Brits choose Scotland or the UK ", because nothing is surer than that the decision will have to be made soon.The Brexit fiasco, engineered by MEGAnationalists, has done us the huge favour of exposing the absurdity of London rule once and for all. England only cares about England and London doesnt even care about north of Watford. The United Kingdom as a political construct is a busted flush.We should put our faith in the younger generation of Scots. Unionist ndash mostly older ndash Scots who "love Scotland"but seem to hate "being Scottish", coupled with the distorting effect ndash demographically speaking ndash of high numbers of English incomers who, by a big majority, are likely to oppose independence, need to be persuaded that we have talent, energy and resources in abundance, and the RIGHT to seek a new path.I am.David RochePerthMartin Redfern states that "the majority of the British public narrowly voted Leave in June ". True enough in England and Wales, but not in Scotland, which voted overwhelmingly to remain within the EU.Mr Redfern stretches credulity to the limit with his argument that Scotland is being listened to by Westminster. Who is listening  Theresa May and her government have spent almost three years contemptuously ignoring the Remain vote in Scotland, and there is a noticeable lack of respect shown by MPs to the SNPs Westminster leader, Ian Blackford, and his colleagues when they speak in Parliament, even though the SNP holds  seats out of Scotlands quota of .So, there may be a majority in the Commons at odds with the Leave vote, but that in no way suggests that MPs have any real interest in or respect for Scotland frankly, they dont give a damn.Ruth Marr,StirlingAs a believer in fulfilling democratic decisions and someone who voted to leave the EU, my response to remainers who are expressing near apoplectic joy at the size of the parliamentary petition to revoke Article  and remain in the EU is this.After all the names of those who are ineligible to vote, including those from Russia, China, North Korea, Europe and where in the world, have been removed from the petition and the total of genuine voters comes to . million+, I will then take it seriously.Paul LewisEdinburghHow can anyone contemplate voting Conservative ever again  No doubt matters will have moved on by the time this is printed but as I writeit is reported that certain ldquoleading Conservative MPs will offer to support the Prime Ministerrsquos Brexit proposalsshe gives an early date for her resignation.They are showing that they have no interest in any concept of whether her ideas are good or bad for the people of the UK countries. Their personal enmity towards her overrides all of that.I have never been a Conservative but I sincerely hope that these self-seeking charlatans will be sent packing by their own electors ndash and the sooner an election is called the better!Gordon RitchieGrantown-on-SpeyExactly  years ago the SNP brought down the government of Jim Callaghan and in an act of unprecedented before or since political self-destruction paved the way for more than a decade of Margaret Thatcher.They suffered heavily for their staggering self-indulgence in placating their zealot wing and at the ensuing General Election were left with one or two of the  MPs they had.Amazingly it would seem, they are about to repeat their  hara-kiri. By merely trying to engineer the worst possible scenario Brexit ndash again to please their far-out wing ndash they may well help bring about a general election.The people of Scotland did not forgive them in  for being unable to see beyond the end of their noses and it is highly likely they will pay a high political price for their one issue obsessiveness a second time.Alexander McKayEdinburghDavid Leask rightly offers the local residents of Glen Etive a chance to speak out against the opposition by wild land proponents who would deny any future development of the human population in a beautul place .A glance at the depopulation of Argyll and Inverness-shire since the late th century by the introduction of sheep ranching and deer stalking tells how much of the glen and Loch Etive-side was made into a manmade wilderness. Well-sculpted hydro as approved by Highland Council will soon blend in.However, a st-century debate on landscape justice is being fronted in Glasgow by Inherit, the Institute for Heritage  Sustainable Human Development. David Leask could well now write on the cultural changes and inclusive approaches they advocate.Then the sterile binary spats of the wild land brigade versus locals can be mediated by sympathetic planning law changes. Scotland needs to promote true bioersity ndash humans and wild nature hand in hand. Glen Etive can be a test bed.Rob GibsonEvanton, Ross-shireNaebudy in Dundeewid say "an ingin wan an aw". They wid say "an ingin ANE an aw".These distinctions are important, Ron ndashdisappointed in you.Poor research ndash tut tut. So unlike you.Love The Diary btw.Dougie ReidLochee, DundeeHaving spent some days in Portree last year, I read Marianne Taylors favourable description of the townwith interest.However, one point that she did not make was the absence of service in Gaelic in hotels, restaurants and cafes. In one hotel the waitress was Czech and I enjoyed a bit of banter in that language, but that is hardly the point.If the parents have given up passing on the language to their children, where is all this Gaelic education going  Despite  years of Sabhal Mor Ostaig and Gaelic schools in Glasgow, Edinburgh, Inverness, Fort William, Portree and where, you could not even get a cup of coffee served to you in the language, and this in the heart of Skye.De tha an clann a deanamh leis an Gaidhlig, an deidh dhaibh an sgoil fhagail What are the children doing with their Gaelic, after they leave school Richard AA DeveriaGaelic HistorianAberfeldy

title: mothers-day-recipes-family-favourites-by-top-scottish-chefs
story: By Giovanna Eusebi of Eusebi Deli in GlasgowMy mum Gina is an ordinary woman with an extraordinary le. Born in December  in the small village of Castelforte in Southern Italy, her path took her from the idyllic Mediterranean village to San Paolo, Lyon and then finally to Glasgow. Food and family were the most important things in her le. Growing up in Italy, good ingredients were available to her throughout the seasons. Breakfast was fresh figs, grapes, and cactus fruit picked from the tree in her garden. If she wanted salad leaves, she stepped outside to cut chicory or dandelion greens. Nature reminded her that no two days were the same and to take each day as it comes.The two biggest factors that influence my cooking are my familyrsquos roots and the seasons. Traditional dishes speak to my heart and fill me with warmth. Knowing these recipes have been enjoyed by previous generations and they have brought happiness to my extended family and friends makes the food even more special. There is nothing better than having your loved ones around a table, all sharing something that you have taken time and effort to prepare. It doesnrsquot have to be dficult or be full of lavish ingredients it just needs to be made with love.It is no coincidence that the sign above our door reads lsquoFood, Family, Le, Passionrsquo. It is a tribute to our extended family all over the world and factors that bring us together ndash great food, wine, cooking, laughter and love.For more information about Eusebi Deli, visit http:eusebideli .Serves Ingredients: burrata, at room temperature small treviso or chicory, quartered waysml balsamic vinegarml extra virgin olive oil, plus extra for serving sprigs of rosemary, stalk removed and finely choppedfrac garlic clove, crushed ripe medium pear, shaved with a vegetable peelerSalt and pepperMethod:. First, prepare the treviso. Preheat the oven to degC and place the treviso on a baking tray and drizzle with the balsamic, olive oil, garlic, rosemary and seasoning. Roast in the oven for  to  minutes or until the treviso is tender and caramelised. Reserve the cooking juice and set aside to cool.. To assemble the dish, place one piece of treviso on each plate and then follow with the burrata. Garnish with a quarter of the shaved pear and drizzle with reserved cooking juices. Finish with a little extra virgin olive and seasoning.Pumpkin Dumplings with Sage  Almond ButterBy Carina ContinildquoGnocchi, or dumplings, are so easy to make. One of my favourite childhood memories was when wersquod get the phone call on a Saturday that Nonna was making gnocchi and would we like to go.This recipe is the next generation iation. Dumplings are made with pumpkin or squash and served with a light butter and sage sauce.Gnocchi are a great thing to get you stuck into cooking and cooking together is always so much more fun. Rolling out the dough and cutting it is something the youngest of the family can get involved in. Sothe family want to cook a treat for me this Motherrsquos Day, this is one recipe they canrsquot get wrong. ndash Carina ContiniCarina Contini is Owner of Contini George Street, Edinburgh Cannonball Restaurant  Bar, Castlehill, Edinburgh and The Scottish Cafe  Restaurant - located at the gardens entrance of the Scottish National Gallery, Edinburgh.Cannonball Restaurant  Bar and Contini George Street in Edinburgh are both open for Motherrsquos Day lunch and dinner bookings. Castle view tables are available at Cannonball. Book ahead and receive a complimentary Motherrsquos Day cocktail. Visit www.contini or call   . Quote ldquoMotherrsquos Day.SERVES IngredientsFor the pumpkin dumplings:g pumpkinpeeled and deseededndash tbsp extra virgin olive oil, for drizzlingSalt and freshly ground black pepperg floury potatoesg plain flour, plus extra for dusting egg yolkFor the sage and almond butter:g whole blanched almondsSprinkle of granulated sugarg unsalted butter sage leavesSaltMethod. Preheat the oven to degC degF Gas . Cut the pumpkin into small pieces and place on a roasting tray. Drizzle with some of the olive oil and add a generous pinch of salt and pepper. Bake in the preheated oven for about  minutes until the pumpkin is soft.. Meanwhile, line a baking tray with greaseproof paper. Peel and cut the potatoes into quarters and put them in a pan with salt and cold water to cover. Bring to the boil, then lower the heat and simmer until tender.. Whilst the potatoes are boiling and the pumpkin is roasting, prepare the sage and almond butter. Put the almonds in a dry non-stick pan and toast over a medium heat until golden. When they start to colour, add the granulated sugar and cook until the sugar has crystallised. Remove from the heat and leave to cool. Once cold, crush with a pestle and mortar or in a food processor. Melt the butter in a small pan and add the sage leaves. When they start to bubble, season with salt. Add the crushed almonds and warm through.. Once the potatoes are tender, drain and mash, then leave in the pan, covered, with a clean tea towel under the lid to help absorb any steam.. Pass the cooked pumpkin through a mouli or mash it until smooth. Transfer the mashed potatoes and pumpkin to a floured surface. Mix together well with your hands. Having the mixture warm will help to keep the dumplings light but be careful not to burn your hands.. Create a well in the centre of the mixture and add the egg yolk and flour, working quickly to keep the mixture as light as possible. Gently knead the mixture together to form a dough. Add a little more flournecessary. Roll the mixture out to a thickness of about cm. Cut into .cm strips and gently roll these into long, smooth sausage shapes. Cut into small cubes using a sharp kne. To add texture, press the back of a fork on top of each cube and quickly move the fork back to make the dumpling curl. This takes a little skill and time but the end result is worth it.. Place the dumplings on the prepared baking tray. This way you wonrsquot need to add more flour and the dumplings wonrsquot go mushy or chalky when cooked.. To cook, bring a large pot of salted water to the boil. Lt the greaseproof paper and dumplings off the tray and immerse the whole lot in the boiling water. The dumplings will be released from the paper. Remove the paper and bring the dumplings to the boil. Once they rise to the surface of the water, reduce the heat and simmer for  minutes. Drain and toss in the sage and almond butter and serve.Seared Gurnard with Wild Garlic and White Wine SauceBy Jerome Henry of Le Roi Fou in EdinburghMy Mother is a keen chef. She is from Haute-Savoie in France and growing up in the countryside, farming and foraging were her way of le. She will never pass by a field of Dandelions, wild berries or wild garlic without stopping and pulling out a pocketkne to gather the fresh plants or fruits. I spent my whole childhood eating freshly picked wild herbs in our lunches that she would prepare for us - it was always delicious.Growing up in Geneva, we were lucky to have a garden where Mom would grow all of our own produce. We enjoyed it fresh, throughout the summer months but we also saved enough for the winter so that we could enjoy the vegetables all year round. We spent most of our family holidays in our house near the sea in the South of France where we would eat freshly caught fish, quickly seared to make the most of the incredible flavour.Wild garlic, or lsquoail de lrsquooursrsquo as we call it in French, is a magical plant that brings sunshine into food after a long dark winter. I always see it as a sign of spring arriving when we can start to find wild leaves in the nearby countryside. This dish is dedicated to my Mom as it reminds me of joyous memories with her, eating fresh fish and picking wild herbs.For more information about Le Roi Fou, visit https:leroou .Serves Ingredients: gurnard filletsOlive oil, for fryingSalt and pepperFor the fish stock:g fish bones and trimmingsg white mirepoix g mushrooms, dicedl water lemon, juice onlySalt and pepperFor the sauce:ml dry white wineml double cream small shallot, finely choppedml fish stock tbsp Noilly PratSalt and freshly ground pepper wild garlic leaves, cut into fine stripsTo serve:Wild garlic leavesSpring greensNew potatoes, steamed. First, make the fish stock. Thoroughly wash the fish bones and trimmings. Sweat the mirepoix and mushrooms in a pot over a medium heat for  minutes. Add the fish bones and trimmings and the water. Bring to a boil and simmer for  minutes, skimming the stock occasionally, then strain it through a fine sieve. Return the stock to the pot and reduce the liquid by half. Season with salt, pepper and lemon juice and then set the pot aside.. Next, make the sauce. Place the white wine and shallots in a pan and cook until the liquid reduces by half. Add the fish stock and reduce again. Add the cream and simmer for  to  minutes. Strain the sauce through a fine sieve. Just before serving, add the wild garlic and Noilly Prat and season to taste.. Next, prepare the fish. Season the gurnard fillets and then heat a non-stick pan on a medium heat. Drizzle a tablespoon of olive oil in the pan and sear the fish fillet, skin down. Gently shake the pan to make sure the fish is not sticking. Cook the fish until the skin is golden and crispy. The flesh on the top side should be almost cooked through. At the last moment, turn the fish over and cook for a few seconds on the flesh side.. To serve, spoon the hot sauce onto four warmed plates and place the gurnard in the centre of the sauce and garnish with wild garlic leaves. Serve the fish with some steamed new potatoes and spring greens.Herb Crusted Rack of Lamb with Dauphinoise Potatoes, Tomato Puree and Broad BeansBy Paul Hart, Executive Sous Chef at GleneaglesThis recipe is my favourite dish to celebrate Motherrsquos Day and what we look forward to every year to mark the occasion. Itrsquos the perfect way to enjoy a special dinner but without having to spend hours in the kitchen. The ingredients are a signal to me that spring is on the horizon with the fresh and delicious flavours of lamb, tomatoes and broad beans. Using soft herbs to create the crust takes it to the next level for a Sunday roast and there is a lovely touch of indulgence with the cream and butter in the dauphinoise potatoes.In our house, we like to get the children involved by peeling the potatoes and shelling the beans. This means that they feel included in the cooking and that theyrsquore also getting to help prepare the special meal for Mum. Many of the elements of the dish can be prepared in advance such as the herb crust, dauphinoise potatoes and tomato puree so it makes cooking on the day super quick and simple.For more information about the Gleneagles, visit https:www.gleneagles  or call the reservations team on  .Serves Ingredients:For the lamb: x  bone racks of lamb, French trimmed slices of bread, crusts removed and blended into a crumbml Scottish rapeseed oilg thyme leaves, choppedg parsley, stalks removed and finely choppedg Parmesan, finely gratedg Dijon mustardSalt and pepperFor the dauphinoise potatoes:kg waxy potatoes, peeled and sliced thinlyml full fat milkml double cream cloves of garlic, peeled and crushed sprigs of thymeSalt and pepperFor the roasted tomato sauce:g cherry tomatoesml red wine vinegarg caster sugarml olive oil garlic clove, peeled and crushedSalt and pepperFor the broad beans:g frozen broad beansg butterml waterg mint leaves, finely choppedSalt and pepperMethod:. First, prepare the lamb. Season the meat with salt and pepper and add the lamb to a cold frying pan. Place the pan on the hob and set to a low to medium heat. As the pan warms it will slowly melt the fat. Let the lamb slowly cook on the fat side until you get a nice golden colour and a crispy piece of fat. Turn the heat up a little and sear the other side of the lamb so that it is coloured all over. Take the lamb out the pan and transfer to a roasting tray, ready for cooking.. In a frying pan, heat the oil and add the breadcrumb. Stir everything together to coat the crumb in oil and season with salt and pepper. Fry the crumbs until golden and crispy. Take the pan off the heat and leave to cool before adding the herbs and Parmesan. Brush the lamb on the fat covered side with Dijon mustard then coat in the herb crumbs.. Next, prepare the dauphinoise potatoes. Toss the potato slices in a bowl with a sprinkling of salt. Add the cream, milk, garlic and thyme to a large pan and bring up to a boil, turn off the heat and leave to infuse for around  minutes. Squeeze the potatoes to remove any excess water, rinse the bowl andthe potatoes. Pour the cream mixture through a sieve onto the potatoes and season as required. Line a deep baking tray with greaseproof paper and place the potatoes into the baking tray in layers so you get a unorm depth, pouring some of the cream between each of the layers. Cover with greaseproof paper and tin foil and bake in the oven at degC for around  to  minutes. You will be able to tell the potatoes are cooked by inserting a skewer into the middle,there is no resistance they are ready.. Next, make the roasted tomato sauce. Cut the tomatoes in half and toss in a bowl with all the other ingredients. Place into a baking dish and roast in the oven at degC for around  to  minutes until the tomatoes slightly blacken around the edges. Place everything into a blender and puree to a smooth sauce. Season as required.. Next, prepare the broad beans. Let the broad beans defrost then squeeze the beans out of the pod. Add the butter and water into a small pan and bring to the boil. Add the beans and cook on a high heat for  minutes or until the water has evaporated and they are coated in butter. Add the seasoning and the chopped mint and stir well to combine everything together.. To cook the lamb, preheat the oven to degC. Cook the lamb for  to  minutes depending on how pink you like it. Once cooked, remove from the oven and just cover with foil. Leave to rest for  minutes before carving into cutlets.. To serve, cut a disk of the dauphinoise potatoes and top with the lamb cutlets. Add the broad beans and the tomato puree to the plate and serve.The Shepherdrsquos DelightMisty Isle Ginrsquos signature cocktailIsle of Skye Distillers is the first gin and vodka distillery on the Isle of Skye. Launched in February  by brothers Alistair and Thomas Wilson, Misty Isle Gin is hand-crafted in small batches using crystal clear waters drawn from the Storr Lochs, just three miles from the distillery. Misty Isle Gin features a precise balance of  botanicals, including hand-foraged juniper berries, coriander, grains of paradise, orris root, liquorice root, black cubebs, lemon peel, cassia bark, and one secret ingredient which can only be found at high altitude on Skye. The result is a gin which is juniper heavy, not too floral, with earthy undertones, a hint of spice and subtle flavours of citrus.Alistair and Thomas recommend serving Misty Isle Gin with a Scottish tonic water, and garnished with a twist of fresh orange peel ndash or why not try Misty Isle Ginrsquos signature cocktail, inspired by the red evening skies on SkyehellipFor more information, visit www.isleofskyedistillersMakes one cocktail.Ingredients:ml Misty Isle Ginml strawberry liqueur.ml elderflower syrup bottle of rose lemonadeCrushed iceA slice of orange peel, to garnishMethod:. Fill a highball glass with crushed ice.. Fill a Boston shaker with cubed ice and add the Misty Isle Gin, the strawberry liqueur and the elderflower syrup.. Shake, then single-strain into the glass, over the crushed ice.. Top the glass up with rose lemonade.. Garnish with a slice of orange peel and a paper straw, and serve.

title: donald-cameron-why-its-time-for-the-tories-to-consider-a-brexit-plan-b
story: Irsquove long advocated the ldquoNorway Plus or ldquoCommon Market . plan as an alternative. This would see us remain in the European Economic Area via membership of EFTA with the UK entering into a comprehensive customs arrangement with the EU. This would deliver frictionless trade and, critically, solve issues around the Irish border because there would be no need for any new regulatory frontier there.Common Market . respects both the outcome of the  referendum but also the closeness of the result. It has the benefit of being an off-the-shelf solution which the EU could agree to immediately, especially when time is in short supply. We would still require a Withdrawal Agreement and the Northern Irish ldquobackstop, but the latter would become academic once we have accessed EFTA. The ldquoPolitical Declaration would be redrafted accordingly to reflect a future relationship with the EU similar to Norwayrsquos.We would exit the Common Fisheries Policy, the Common Agricultural Policy, and the jurisdiction of the Court of Justice. We would remain outside the Schengen "open borders" regime. We would have scope in time to become a party to EFTAs existing free trade agreements and to strike our own international trade deals, just as Iceland has with China.In short, we would leave the political institutions of the EU and move away from ldquoever closer Union. But at the same time, and as the name of this plan suggests, the proposal goes to the heart of what we joined in the first place: namely, a common market.Itrsquos not perfect by any means. The UK would still have to make financial contributions into the EU, although at a signicantly lower level than we do at present. Itrsquos associate membership, where we pay for what we access. EFTA states are often caricatured as docile rule-takers enduring ldquotaxation without representation. Yet the reality of EFTA membership is a lot more nuanced. EFTA countries are in fact involved in major EU ldquodecision-shaping mechanisms as well as having participation rights in a number of EU programmes and organisations. We would not be a voting member state, but as a major European economy and home to the continentrsquos principal financial centre, we would retain a powerful influence on many of the issues facing Europe as a whole.Common Market . is a compromise, without doubt. But like the best compromises, itrsquos a pragmatic and realistic solution which endeavours to bridge the gap between two extremes.It avoids the bitter rancour of another referendum on the one hand and the chaos of a ldquono-deal Brexit on the other. Itrsquos a plan which respects the integrity of the United Kingdom. If the Prime Ministerrsquos deal falls, surely itrsquos worth contemplating Donald Cameron is the Conservative MSP for the Highlands and Islands. He is also the Policy Co-ordinator for his partys  Holyrood manesto

title: former-tory-cabinet-nicky-morgan-minister-says-brexit-may-require-a-national-unity-government
story: Border Communities Against Brexit organised the protests to mark the day after Britain had been due to leave the European Union.It came after a former Tory cabinet minister warned Britain may need a government of national unity.Nicky Morgan said a cross-party coalition may be the only way to break the deadlock.The border demonstrations yesterday took place along a number of crossing points in Co Tyrone, Co Louth, Co Donegal, Co Fermanagh, Co Cavan and Co Monaghan.Demonstrators set up a mock check-point on the Old Dublin Road in Carrickcarnon which was manned by people dressed as customs officers.The road was closed to members of the public as protesters carried anti-Brexit placards and EU flags.Sinn Fein president Mary Lou McDonald was joined by party vice-president Michelle ONeill and Newry and Armagh Sinn Fein Assembly member Conor Murphy.Border Communities Against Brexit spokesman Declan Fearon warned a crash Brexit is "increasingly likely".He said: "A border in the past meant this road was closed for over  years and this community was ided."We wont allow the very hard right-wing Tories and the ERGand especially the DUP to destroy this community and bring us back to days when this was an economic wasteland."Around  people gathered at the border on a road that was closed during the Troubles.Many similar protests were staged on ious border points between Northern Ireland and the Republic.Colin Harvey, a professor of human rights law at Queens University Belfast School of Law, said he is against any attempt to "undermine or attack" the Good Friday Agreement.He said: "We have long experience of people trying to put walls in our way and we take them down."If anybody attempts to put barriers on this island again they are coming down. Any obstacles on this island will be removed."We as a society are used to people putting up mountains for us to climb and we will continue to climb them. There will be no hard border on the island of Ireland."We are going to be the generation who ends the major ision on this island, who can achieve the unication of our own country and we are going to get there."Ms McDonald said: "We are at a very dangerous moment where we inch ever closer to the real possibility of a crash and a chaotic Brexit."At this stage people should understand how serious that would be for all of us."The reality is that Brexit in any form is a disaster for the island of Ireland."She also accused the DUP of being "seduced" by Westminster.She added: "The people who live in the north of Ireland wish to continue in a society that is someway prosperous, thats stable and many people identy not just as Irish but also as Europeans. They did not consent to Brexit."They will never, never, never give up on that point either."Local student Aine Quinn, who lives along the border, said Brexit will bring economic chaos to the area.She said: "Yesterday was supposed to be Brexit day and today we are no clearer on what that means than we were three years ago."What we do know is that there are no good outcomes for us. The British Government tried to dismiss us as a small issue among other big issues."The main problem for me and my community is the free movement of people, whether to work, study or trade."The Commons is due to hold a second round of indicative votes tomorrow on alternatives to Mayrsquos plan amid warnings that Westminster is rapidly running out of time to resolve the crisis.With the Prime Minister determined to bring back her deal for a fourth time, Nicky Morgan saidMPs were able to coalesce around one of the alternatives it may need a unity government to implement it.ldquoIf the Government refused and Theresa May felt she could not implement what Parliament had identied as a way of leaving the EU, then I think we would have to think very hard about whether a cross-party coalition, group of people, whatever, could do that in order to make sure that the UK does leave the EU in an orderly fashion, she told the BBC.The former education secretary ndash touted as a possible ldquounity prime minister ndash added: ldquoIt may well be thatyou end up with a cross-party approach to finding a majority in the House of Commons it might be that you need a cross-party approach to implementing it.ldquoThere have been periods in our history when we have had national unity governments or a coalition for a very specic issue.Her comments came after Labour deputy leader Tom Watson suggested the time had come for a national unity government.In an interview with Prospect magazine, he said: ldquoI prefer Labour governments and I hope we never get to a point where our economy or security is so in peril that we get a government of national unity.But he added: ldquoIf needs must, we have to then do whatrsquos right.There appeared to be little enthusiasm for the prospect among those around Jeremy Corbyn. Shadow transport secretary Andy McDonald said: ldquoIrsquom not sure thatrsquos going to be the solution.Conservative Party chairman Brandon Lewis also rejected the idea, insisting Mayrsquos deal was still the best way to deliver an orderly withdrawal from the EU.Lewis made clear the Government remained opposed to the option which came closest to a majority in the first round of votes on Wednesday ndash a proposal by veteran Tory Ken Clarke for a customs union.ldquoThere would be a huge number of people around the country who would understandably take the view that doesnrsquot respect thevote of  and it goes against our partyrsquos manesto, he said.In this weekrsquos indicative votes, the SNP did not support the Clarke plan, a proposal that was narrowly defeated.In an article for this newspaper, Blackford said retaining EU membership is ldquoby far the best deal of all and stopping Brexit ldquomust be the priority. However, he argued that the SNP will ldquocontinue our talks across the parties and, in the event that Brexit goes ahead, wrote that ldquoprotecting our membership of the single market and customs union would be crucial.He added: ldquoWhile I have limited confidence in Westminster to act in Scotlandrsquos interests ndash the SNP will do everything we can to reach out, build consensus, and find a way out of this crisis.Meanwhile, the Prime Minister is under renewed pressure from the Brexiter wing of the party after she said it was ldquoalmost certain that there would have to be an extended delay to Brexither deal does not go through.Following the defeat on Friday, she warned the Commons would not allow Britain to leave without a deal on April  ndash the new deadline set by the EU.Any signicant extension beyond that date would require Britain to take part in elections in May to the European Parliament.A newspaper report claimed that  Tory MPs had now written to the Prime Minister demanding the UK leaves within the next few months and insisting it cannot take part in the European elections.The letter was said to have been signed by  members of the Cabinet ndash including Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt and Home Secretary Sajid Javid ndash and  other ministers.Lewis said: ldquoI havenrsquot signed the letter. I do know about it. I havenrsquot seen the full text of the letter and I havenrsquot seen the signatures on it.ldquoMy view is that we should be doing everything we can to leave the European Union in good order as quickly as we can. I think the deal is the right way to do that.ldquoWe must do everything we can to ensure we do not fight the European elections. None of us wants to do that.In another development, Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn accused the Tory Government of ldquorunning down the clock and ldquobullying and threatening MPs in order to force through Mayrsquos Brexit deal.He also refused to say whether his party would offer an option to remain in the European Union during a second round of indicative votes in the House of Commons tomorrow.Corbyn was speaking from Newport in South Wales yesterday as he joined Labour candidate Ruth Jones ahead of the Newport West by-election next week.AskedLabourrsquos indicative vote would include an option of giving the public a confirmatory referendum on any Brexit deal, Corbyn said: ldquoThat is the Labour position so far but there hasnrsquot been enough support for that across the floor in the House of Commons.ldquoBut the absolute priority atthe moment is to end this chaos the Government has brought us to by their endlessly running down the clock and basically bullying and threatening people.ldquoThe bullying hasnrsquot worked the threats hasnrsquot worked. Itrsquos time now for the sensible people to take over.

title: mums-the-word-six-interesting-facts-about-mothers-day
story: Motherrsquos Day is the international occasion when children of all ages say thank you to the most important person in their le.But what are the origins of today, and how is it celebrated  Rozlyn Little takes a look behind the chocolates and flowers to find a few interesting facts.. The date changes every year: The origins of Motherrsquos Day began hundreds of years ago. The festivity originally had religious connections, and it was traditional for people to worship at their ldquomother church ndash the largest church in the area ndash during Lent. This allowed families to attend the event together, and children who were often separated from their families during work periods, wouldwith gts for their mothers.Eventually, this became a less common practice with a decline in church attendance, but it enjoyed a resurgence through American influence during World War II. Since then, the event has lost most of its religious connections, but continues to be held on the fourth Sunday of Lent. It has also adopted the mass commercialisation which is favoured by America. The most popular forms of gts are greeting cards, flowers and chocolates, with ldquoexperience gts ndash such as spa days and afternoon teas ndash also becoming a favoured option.. The British spend twice as much on Motherrsquos Day as they do on Fatherrsquos Day: This year, UK spending for Motherrsquos Day increased .% on  to pound.bn ndash proving it is one of the most important commercial events of the year. It has been suggested that the reason for the extra spending is many people believe their mum has made a larger sacrice and deserves more. Itrsquos also thought that shoppers find it more dficult to buy gts for their dad, who may not be as interested in chocolates and flowers. A pair of socks and a Lynx set usually does seem to be enoughhellip. Many people will be running out to get their mumrsquos a last-minute gt this morning: In the lead up to the event, masses of online articles are dedicated to the perfect last-minute gt, complete with a convenient link to buy online. According to statistics, the sale of cut flowers and indoor plants increases by an average of % on the day ndash making the event one of the most important for the floral industry. Mothers Day even tops Valentinersquos Day, with men spending more on honouring their mums than their romantic partners.. More than  countries around the world celebrate some form of Mothers Day: It is a recognised holiday in many countries, and in Paraguay it coincides with Independence Day, known as Dia de la Patria. However, so many people ignored the countryrsquos independence in favour of their mum that, in , the countryrsquos cultural minister called for Motherrsquos Day to be moved to the end of the month, in a bid to give the countrys independence a look-in. A group of young people even petitioned parliament about moving Motherrsquos Day. It remains unchanged and is celebrated on May , with schools and children presenting poetry to recognise the importance of maternal figures in their society.. More phone calls are made on Motherrsquos Day than any other: Whatrsquos better than a generic card and a box of chocolates  Spending time with your mum. When this isnrsquot possible, a phone call or Skype call is the next best thing. The frequency and the duration of the calls even tops the ones made on New Yearrsquos and Valentinersquos Day, showing just how much people value their mums.. Nearly every language in the world has a similar word for mother: The word ldquomama is recognised almost universally ndash and around the world it is often among the first words babies speak. It was Russian Linguist Roman Jakobson who tried to explain the words usage in a study titled "Mama and Papa". He said that as babies experiment with speaking, they often make the easiest sounds available to them ndash ldquommm and ldquoaah. When this is repeated, it starts to form something close to ldquoma-ma ndash a huge source of pride to every mum, even though the baby is actually wanting fed.

story: Ian Wright, chief executive of the Food and Drink Federation, said a no-deal Brexit would cause ldquoenormous amounts of disruption and enormous amounts of dficulty for its members.He told BBC Breakfast: ldquoThe real problem here is that the disruption that we would have from no deal would very quickly lead to empty shelves, it would lead to more expensive products, and it would lead to a real diminution of choice ndash particularly for people in poorer areas and at the end of distribution chains.Mr Wright said most of the federationrsquos members would be ldquohorried by the imposition of tarfs on EU trade, adding: ldquoIrsquom absolutely terried of the prospects for our economy and our food and drink industry by the prospect of tarfs.ldquoIt will cause enormous amounts of disruption and enormous amounts of dficulty.Brexit-supporting Wetherspoons founder Tim Martin highlighted that leaving the EU will allow the UK to lt existing tarfs on trade with countries outside the bloc.ldquoWersquoll have far less tarfs on New Zealand wine, on rice, on oranges, on bananas, he told the broadcaster.ldquoIf we leave the EU without a deal the number of tarfs will be vastly reduced.
